issues.description: The problem statement and the template code expect a no-argument method messageOnMilk() that returns a String (see UML and Part 2 description). The solution repository instead defines Milkable.messageOnMilk(double volume) (and Seal/Goat implement messageOnMilk(double)), i.e., the method takes a double parameter. This parameter mismatch means the solution's interface and implementations are incompatible with the problem specification and with the template's example usage (template Main calls m.messageOnMilk() with no argument). Students following the problem/template will implement a no-arg messageOnMilk(), but the provided solution and its Milkable interface use a different signature, causing compilation errors and confusion.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the Milkable interface consistent with the problem statement and template. Either:
1) Remove the volume parameter: change Milkable.messageOnMilk(double) to Milkable.messageOnMilk() returning String, and update Seal and Goat to implement the no-arg version returning the specified string format (e.g., "Seal Clarabelle is milked"). Also ensure example/template Main and any tests call messageOnMilk() with no arguments. OR
2) If a volume parameter was intended, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main to document and call messageOnMilk(double volume) and adjust the example usage to pass a volume value. The preferred fix to preserve the exercise as described is option (1): revert to a no-argument messageOnMilk().

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a parameterless method messageOnMilk() that returns a string like "[Animal Type] [name] is milked" (see UML and Part 2). The solution repository instead defines Milkable.messageOnMilk(double volume) (and implementations in Seal and Goat) — i.e., the same conceptual operation (milking an animal) is represented with a different method signature in the solution. This mismatch breaks the straightforward mapping from the task description/template usage (which call messageOnMilk() with no argument) to the solution API, and will confuse students (and produce compile errors if mixing template Main code and the provided solution).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method signature across artifacts. Prefer updating the solution to match the problem/template: change the Milkable interface to String messageOnMilk() (no parameters) and update Seal and Goat implementations to return "[Animal Type] [name] is milked". Alternatively, if the intended design requires a volume parameter, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main usage to declare and call messageOnMilk(double volume) and update the textual specification accordingly. The first option (removing the volume parameter from the solution) is recommended to minimize changes to the assignment text and template.
